text.headline:
Pre World War II
Major Events
text.text: This is a timeline of all the major events that led up to the start of World War 2.

text.headline: Treaty of Versailles Signed
text.text: On June 28, 1919, the Treaty of Versailles was signed at the Palace of Versailles, officially ending World War I. The treaty imposed strict reparations and territorial losses on Germany and laid the groundwork for geopolitical tensions that would later lead to World War II.

text.headline: Mussolini Takes Power in Italy
text.text: On October 31, 1922, Benito Mussolini became Prime Minister of Italy after the March on Rome. This marked the beginning of Fascist rule in Italy and Mussolini's rise as a totalitarian dictator.

text.headline: Occupation of the Ruhr
text.text: On January 11, 1923, French and Belgian troops occupied Germany's Ruhr Valley after Germany failed to make reparations payments required by the Treaty of Versailles. The occupation escalated tensions in postwar Europe and crippled the German economy, contributing to hyperinflation and unrest.

text.headline: Beer Hall Putsch
text.text: On November 8–9, 1923, Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party attempted to overthrow the Weimar government in what became known as the Beer Hall Putsch. The coup failed, and Hitler was arrested and sentenced to prison, during which he wrote Mein Kampf.

text.headline: Hitler Appointed Chancellor of Germany
text.text: On January 30, 1933, Adolf Hitler was appointed Chancellor of Germany by President Paul von Hindenburg. This marked a critical turning point that enabled Hitler to dismantle democratic institutions and establish a totalitarian Nazi regime.

text.headline: Reichstag Fire
text.text: On February 27, 1933, the German parliament building (Reichstag) was set on fire in Berlin. The Nazis blamed the communists and used the incident to justify the Reichstag Fire Decree, which suspended civil liberties and allowed mass arrests, helping Hitler consolidate power.

text.headline: Night of the Long Knives
text.text: From June 30 to July 2, 1934, Adolf Hitler carried out a series of political purges known as the Night of the Long Knives. The Nazi regime arrested and executed members of the SA (Sturmabteilung) and other political opponents to consolidate Hitler's absolute power in Germany.

text.headline: Death of Paul von Hindenburg
text.text: On August 2, 1934, President Paul von Hindenburg died at the age of 86. His death allowed Adolf Hitler to merge the offices of Chancellor and President, declaring himself Führer of Germany and securing total control of the state.

text.headline: Germany Remilitarizes the Rhineland
text.text: On March 7, 1936, Adolf Hitler defied the Treaty of Versailles and the Locarno Pact by sending German troops into the demilitarized Rhineland. This move was met with little resistance from France or Britain. A month later, a national referendum overwhelmingly approved Hitler's actions, further consolidating his control and emboldening Nazi foreign policy.

text.headline: Annexation of Austria (Anschluss)
text.text: On March 12, 1938, German troops crossed the border into Austria and completed the annexation of the country in what became known as the Anschluss. The move was welcomed by many Austrians and later ratified by a manipulated plebiscite, further expanding Nazi Germany's territory without military conflict.

text.headline: Occupation of the Sudetenland
text.text: On October 1, 1938, German troops entered the Sudetenland, a region of Czechoslovakia with a large ethnic German population. The occupation was authorized by the Munich Agreement, signed by Britain, France, Italy, and Germany—without Czechoslovak involvement. In March 1939, Hitler violated the agreement by occupying the rest of Czechoslovakia, marking a major step toward World War II.

text.headline: Kristallnacht (Night of Broken Glass)
text.text: On the night of November 9–10, 1938, Nazi paramilitary forces and civilians carried out coordinated attacks against Jews throughout Nazi Germany and Austria. Synagogues were burned, Jewish-owned businesses and homes were vandalized and looted, and around 30,000 Jewish men were arrested and sent to concentration camps. Kristallnacht marked a major escalation in Nazi anti-Jewish policy and the path toward the Holocaust.
